Williams   (Dartmouth)       Greg Wilsbacher   (USC MIRC)         Audrey Young   (Cineteca Nacional México)       Yvonne Zimmermann   (U of Zurich / NYU)              Presenter Bio                 Richard Allen   is Professor and Chair of Cinema Studies at New York University. He is author of   Projecting Illusion   (1995),   Hitchcock's Romantic Irony   (2007), coauthor of   Islamicate Cultures of Bombay Cinema   (2009), and coeditor of the   Hitchcock Annual   , the journal of Hitchcock Studies, and six books in the fields of film theory and aesthetics.               Michael Aronson   is Director of Cinema Studies at the University of Oregon. His “silent cine tip o da day,” a daily Twitter feed about online early film resources can be followed @MichaelAronson.               Issa García Ascot   is a filmmaker who studied directing at Universidad Autónoma Nacional de México and its Center for Cinematographic Studies. She also studied acting in New York and in 2004 received a Rockefeller Grant for Media Artists. She is currently learning to make bread.               Danielle Ash   is a multimedia animator, and 2010 recipient of the Orphan Film Symposium's Helen Hill Award.   Her stop-motion animations made of cardboard, clay, wire, tape, and a wide array of found objects have screened in festivals from Vienna to Los Angeles. In 2010, she was awarded the Stellar Animation Award at the Black Maria Film Festival for her thesis film,   Pickles for Nickels   . Now based in New York, Ash is currently teaching and working in animation and title design. She received her BFA at the School of Art Institute of Chicago and her MFA in experimental animation at CalArts in 2008.               Harrison M. Beck   is an actor and music director, graduating from the Tisch school at New York University with a BFA in drama and a minor in music this May. He has most recently appeared in   That Beautiful Laugh   (La Mama etc), and as Cymbeline in     Shakespeare's   Cymbeline   (Classical Studio New York University). He directed music for and   The Word Orgy   (Classical Studio, New York University), as well as for   That Beautiful Laugh   . He is honored to be a part of this process of bringing an orphaned film back to life!               Howard Besser   is Director of NYU's Moving Image Archiving and Preservation Program. He has written extensively about copyright, and is a co-author of   The Digital Dilemma   , the National Research Council's study of the implications of information age technology on intellectual property. He was also a co-founder of the American Library Association's Information Commons Initiative Group, which focused on how intellectual property laws impeded the building of a true commons of information.               Jim Bittl   is a 2010 graduate of the NYU Cinema Studies master's program who works at HBO.               Bill Brand   is an artist, educator, and film preservationist. His films and videos are seen worldwide in museums, festivals, and on television. His 1980 public artwork     Masstransiscope   , an animated mural, is installed in the subway in Brooklyn and in the MTA Arts for Transit permanent collection. He is Professor of Film and Photography at Hampshire     College as well as an adjunct professor teaching film preservation in the NYU MIAP program. His company BB     Optics offers archival preservation of small-gauge films and films by artists. In 2006 he was named an Anthology Film Archives Film Preservation Honoree.               Michal Bregant   is a film historian, critic, and curator. He has worked as editor-in-chief of the journal       Iluminace   ; a board member of the State Fund for the Support and Development of Czech Cinema; and at FAMU, the Prague Film Academy, as Dean (2002 – 2008) and Chair of FAMU International (2008 – 2012). In January 2012 he was appointed director of the Czech National Film Archive, where, from 1987 to 2002, he worked as a curator and researcher. He teaches courses in film history and theories of drama at FAMU, and in 1998 was a visiting professor in the Department of Slavic Languages at the University of Texas at Austin.               Jeanne Gooden Burkhardt   is a granddaughter of Francena Bickling,       the 13-year-old star of       Francena       Feeding the Chickens,       shot in 1905 by       Francena’s uncle, Charles Camp.       Jeanne,       a university librarian for 25 years,       resides in Las Cruces, New Mexico.       This January she       and her husband Ross       completed a 51-minute       iMovie on the Camp       family       based on historic       letters and photographs, embedding in it the digitized film fragment of   Francena   . Two other grandchildren of the late Francena -- Jeanne's first cousins       Susan       Gooden       Galbraith (Sandwich, MA) and Eugene       Gooden       Martin       (East Brunswick, NJ) –       are attending the on-screen debut of their grandmother at Orphans 8.                   Tina Campt   is Director of Africana Studies and Professor of Africana and Women’s Studies at Barnard College, Columbia University. Campt’s work theorizes gendered, racial, and diasporic formation in black communities in Germany, and Europe more broadly. She is the author of two books:   Other Germans: Black Germans and the Politics of Race, Gender and Memory in the Third Reich   (2004) is an oral history of Black Germans in the Third Reich; and her most recent book,   Image Matters: Archive, Photography and the African Diaspora     in Europe   (2012) explores early twentieth century family photography of Black Germans and Black Britons.             Jeff Capp   is Project Manager for Gartenberg Media Enterprises, involved in all aspects of the company business. He has worked extensively on vetting the libraries of film collections, and spearheaded the expansion of the company’s profile to incorporate DVD distribution of international classic films.     He has also held positions with various distribution and exhibition companies gaining knowledge of all aspects of film and video distribution and exhibition such as Landmark Theatres, New Yorker Films, and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Capp holds a B.A. in Cinema Studies from New York University and currently lives in Portland, Oregon.               Mark Garrett Cooper   is Professor of Film and Media Studies and English at the University of South Carolina, where he also serves as Interim Director of Moving Image Research Collections. A specialist in the filmmaking institutions of early Hollywood, Cooper has published two books and numerous scholarly articles. He has spoken on silent cinema and film archives to audiences in Athens, Beijing, Bologna, Guadalajara, Montreal, Stockholm, and across the United States. He is currently working on two books, one devoted to the art of motion picture accounting practices and another collaborative project with John Marx (UC Davis) that promises to explain how Hollywood defined the Humanities disciplines.               Susan Courtney   is associate professor of Film and Media Studies and English at the University of South Carolina, where she was a co-founder of the Orphan Film Symposium. Originally trained as a scholar of popular U.S. feature films -- as reflected in her first book,   Hollywood Fantasies of Miscegenation --   her years of working with and attending Orphans have influenced the more expanded field of her current research. She is finishing a book project, "Split Screen Nation: Moving Images of the West, the South, and the USA," that considers the role of moving image culture in the dramatic reimagining of the U.S. that took place in the 1950s and 1960s. This project considers Hollywood films, but also amateur, industrial, and atomic test films.               Nell Cox   is a producer-director known for her work both in fiction and nonfiction. Early in her career as documentary editor and director, she collaborated with the founders of American cinema verite (Richard Leacock, Robert Drew, D. A. Pennebaker, and the Maysles brothers). In the 1970s and 80s, she directed episodes of some of the most popular narrative television series, including   L.A. Law, The Waltons, Lou Grant, The Love Boat,   and   M*A*S*H,   as well as PBS series   American Playhouse, Great Performances,   and   Ghostwriter.   She returned to documentary, dividing her time between New York and her home state of Kentucky. Her recent documentary,   Sweet Tooth   (2011), profiles a dentist treating children in Appalachia. Cox is working on a documentary about expanded consciousness and psychoactive plants.               Dave Davidson   is an award-winning documentary maker and media educator. His latest film as director,   A Place Out of Time: The Bordentown School,   premiered on PBS in 2010. He is now coproducing the third season of the PBS series,   Michael Feinstein’s American Songbook.   Davidson is also now completing the long form documentary   Han Richter: Everything Turns, Everything Revolves,   due for release in 2013. He is the founding Director of the MFA in Media Arts Production Program at the City College of New York.               Nico de Klerk   is an independent researcher in Holland who has presented materials at all eight editions of the Orphan Film Symposium. His professional interests have always been focused on orphans, in the extended sense of materials being neglected or not prioritized in terms of preservation, research or presentation (e.g. early nonfiction film, colonial cinema, home movies or the program format). He has presented his work in the series of Amsterdam Workshops at the Nederlands Filmmuseum, in programs, and in publications. He is on the executive committee of Domitor and the editorial board of the AMIA journal   The Moving Image   .               Ethan de Seife       Ethan de Seife is Assistant Professor of Film Studies at Hofstra University. His book   Tashlinesque: The Hollywood Comedies of Frank Tashlin   , has just been published by Wesleyan University Press. He is also the author of the Cultographies volume on   This Is Spinal Tap   , and blogs at ethandeseife.wordpress.com.               Jo Dery   is an interdisciplinary artist who experiments with animation, drawings, prints, and illustrations. Her work has been presented in her own videos, films, installation projects, and small book publications. Currently an Assistant Professor of Animation in DePaul University’s School of Cinema and Interactive Media, Dery has screened her work in such festivals as the Ann Arbor Film Festival and the International Film Festival Rotterdam, and exhibited her drawings and prints in New York, Providence, San Francisco, Portland, and Los Angeles.               Manthia Diawara   is director of NYU's Institute of Afro American Affairs and director of the Africana Studies program. He is also a professor of cinema studies. His films and books attempt to analyze and study the social and historical black experience in America as well as abroad. Some of his authored books are   We Won't Budge: An African Exile in the World   ,   In Search of Africa   and   Black American Cinema: Aesthetics and Spectatorship   . Some of his films include   Rouch in Reverse   ,   In Search of Africa, and Masion Tropicale.                 Skip Elsheimer   is a media archeologist making his extensive collection 16mm educational films available under the name A/V Geeks. With the slogan “Have 24,000 films will travel” on his website, Elsheimer gives 16mm and film strip shows across the U.S. He has work on archival film projects for NASA, the Internet Archive, and others. A member of the Center for Home Movies board of directors, he has also published essays in   The Moving Image   and the book   Learning with the Lights Off: Educational Film in the United States   (2012). He attended the first Orphan Film Symposium.               Bill Ferehawk       is a founding member of the Society for Moving Images about the Built Environment and co-owner       of Radiant Features. His directorial credits include the documentary films   Lustron: The House America’s Been Waiting For   (2004);   Eero Saarinen: Shaping the Future   (2009);   True to Form: Vladamir Ossipoff, Architect   (2007); and   Aloha Buddha: The Story of Japanese Buddhism in Hawaii   (2011). He is currently directing a feature documentary about the early history of the biotechnology industry. Ferehawk studied art history at UC Berkeley and architecture at Yale. He lives in mid-city Los Angeles with his family.               Allyson Nadia Field   is an assistant professor of Cinema and Media Studies at UCLA. Her research focuses on race and ethnicity in American films. In 2007-08 she became a Sheila Biddle Ford Foundation Fellow at the W. E. B. Du Bois Institute for African American Research at Harvard. She is currently completing her book   Filming Uplift and Projecting Possibility,   detailing African American uplift films of the 1910s. She is also co-curator of a major film series, "L.A. Rebellion: Creating a New Black Cinema," which will tour internationally. With Jan-Christopher Horak and Jacqueline Stewart, she is editing the book   To Emancipate the Image: The L.A. Rebellion of Black Filmmakers.                 Adrianne Finelli   is an experimental documentarian who focuses on the “repressed and undocumented” family histories through single-channel video, audio collages, and multimedia installations. Her 2012 work   Too Soon Too Late   uses found footage from the 1950s-1960s in an exploration of her own family history. Finelli currently teaches time-based media at the University of Michigan's School of Art & Design.               Walter Forsberg   was born in Saskatchewan, and now works as a Research Fellow at NYU Libraries. From 2005 to 2008 he created films and art projects with Winnipeg's L'Atelier national du Manitoba. He is currently working to preserve early computer animation films made at Bell Laboratories. Forsberg graduated from the MIAP program in 2010.               Dan Friedlaender   is an adjunct professor in film and media studies at Temple University. In   1998 he received his MFA in filmmaking from Columbia University, and while there helped the school excavate its own collection of forgotten films. With Adrianne Finelli he contributed video to the   50 Screens   exhibition at the 2012 Ann Arbor Film Festival.               Jon Gartenberg   is president of Gartenberg Media Enterprises. GME restores and distributes libraries of classic and avant-garde films, and archives of publishing and photographic assets. He has lectured and written numerous articles on film history and archiving. As a curator and distributor presents material ranging from early cinema to the latest cutting edge experimental films. Gartenberg has also served as an archival consultant on many film projects, and GME has licensed clips from avant-garde artists’ works for television productions, including PBS documentaries on Bob Dylan, Andy Warhol, and the history of New York.               Hadi Gharabaghi   is a PhD candidate in Cinema Studies at NYU. His dissertation research involves historical and theoretical investigations into imperial sponsorship of educational and propaganda films, specifically, the U.S. Information Agency's project in Iran during the 1950s and 1960s.               Faye Ginsburg   is David B. Kriser Professor of Anthropology at NYU. She is founder and Director of the Center for Media, Culture and History, as well as the Program in Culture and Media, a joint certificate project of Anthropology and Cinema Studies. Ginsburg also co-directs both the Center for Religion and Media and the NYU Council for the Study of Disability. For her academic work, she has won numerous grants and awards including a Guggenheim and a MacArthur. Her book Mediating Culture: Indigenous Identity in a Digital Age is forthcoming from Duke University Press. Her current research with anthropologist Rayna Rapp focuses on Cultural Innovation, Citizenship, and Learning Disabilities.               Carl Goodman   became Director of Museum of the Moving Image in 2011. A composer of electronic music, he joined the museum in 1989 to develop programs related to digital technology in filmmaking. In 1992, Moving Image named him Curator of Digital Media, a first for a major museum. As Senior Deputy Director, Goodman oversaw public programming, education, and collections initiatives. Among the exhibits he has organized are Computer Space (1995), a history of video games, and Real Virtuality (2011) the inaugural exhibition in the expanded and renovated building. Goodman also serves as project director for Collection Space, an international collaboration developing open-source, web-based collections management software for use by museums worldwide.               Annette Groschke   graduated from the L. Jeffrey Selznick School of Film Preservation at George Eastman House and has been working as a film archivist and cataloguer at Deutsche Kinemathek - Museum für Film und Fernsehen since 2004. Recently, she completed reconstructions of two Asta Nielsen films:   Die Suffragette   (1913) and   Das Liebes ABC   (1916). For the 2012 edition of Le Giornate del Cinema Muto she has curated two programs of silent German animation films with Doris Hackbarth of Bundesarchiv, Berlin.               Tom Gunning   is Distinguished Service Professor in the Department on Cinema and Media at the University of Chicago. He is author of   D.W. Griffith and the Origins of American Narrative Film   (1991),   The Films of Fritz Lang: Allegories of Vision and Modernity   (2000), and more than one hundred articles. With Andre Gaudreault he originated the influential theory of the “cinema of attractions.” In 2009 he was awarded an Andrew A. Mellon Distinguished Achievement Award, the first film scholar to receive one, and in 2010 was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Gunning is currently working on a book about the invention of the moving image.               David Hansen   is the Digital Library Fellow for Berkeley Law’s Digital Library Copyright Project. His work investigates copyright obstacles faced by libraries and like-minded organizations in their efforts to realize the full potential of present and future digital library initiatives.   Before coming to Berkeley he       was in the Office of Scholarly Communications at Duke University, where he worked on open access and copyright related matters. He is a graduate of the University of North Carolina School of Law, and is in the final stages of an MLIS degree from UNC's School of Library and Information Science.               Martha Harsanyi   provided the reference service for the Indiana University Audio-Visual Center for over thirty years. This was one of the earliest and largest university-based film collections in the country, and IU was a leader in the field of audiovisual instruction. In 2006 she and the collection (including about 48,000 16mm reels) moved to the Libraries, where these films form the bulk of the IU Libraries Film Archive. She is currently media collections manager for the IU Libraries.               Heather   Heckman   is an Assistant Director and Curator at the University of South Carolina's Moving Image Research Collections.   She   is a PhD candidate in Communication Arts (Film Studies) at UW-Madison, where she also earned an MA in Library and Information Studies. Her dissertation is a history of Hollywood's transition to Eastmancolor. Heckman's publications include       "Burn After Viewing, or, Fire in the Vaults: Nitrate Decomposition and       Combustibility," in   American Archivist   (Winter 2010) and a forthcoming       article on Technicolor design in John Ford's   Drums Along the Mohawk   .               Karl Heider   is Carolina Distinguished Professor, Emeritus, at the University of South Carolina, from which he retired in 2008 after a lengthy teaching career in the Department of Anthropology. He is currently teaching at the University of Tokyo. As a filmmaker, his work began with   Tikal   (1961), documenting the archaeological excavation of a Mayan house mound in Guatemala (although his cinematic career might be said to have begun when he played a prisoner of war in the 1957 release   Bridge on the River Kwai   ). Heider helped shoot Robert Gardner's ethnographic film classic   Dead Birds   (1964) and made his own films about a Papuan society in West New Guinea,   Dani Sweet Potatoes   and   Dani Houses   (released in 1974). His work is now distributed by Documentary Educational Resources.                       A noted scholar of anthropology, he received his PhD from Harvard in 1966. In 1975, Heider worked with Margaret Mead, John Marshall, Sol Worth,   Walter Goldschmidt, John Adair, Timothy Asch, and Jay Ruby to found the National Anthropological Film Center, now the Smithsonian's Human Studies Film Archives.   His widely referenced book   Ethnographic Film   has remained in print since 1976, with a revised edition issued in 2006. Among his many books since are   Indonesian Cinema: National Culture on Screen   and   Landscapes of Emotion: Mapping Three Cultures of Emotion in Indonesia   (both 1991).                        To honor Karl Heider's longtime support for the Orphan Film Symposium, NYU MIAP students and BB Optics preserved Karl's surviving 16mm print of   Studies of Apparent Behavior,   a film made by his father in 1943. A renowned psychologist, Fritz Heider made the animated piece with Marianne Simmel for what became a landmark study in social perception.               Jennifer Horne   is Assistant Professor of Film and Digital Media at the University of California, Santa Cruz. She is writing a book that recovers the history of motion picture use by social reformers, educators, cultural institutions, and civic associations and explores the interplay of civic participation and film exhibition. She has represented the Society for Cinema and Media Studies on the National Film Preservation Board since 2005. Most recently, Jennifer contributed an article on the use of motion pictures by American public libraries in the 1910s and 1920s to the anthology   Useful Cinema   (2011), edited by Charles Acland and Haidee Wasson. Horne's essay on the motion picture division of the American Red Cross is forthcoming in   Beyond the Screen   , published by Domitor. She attended the first Orphan Film Symposium.               Dennis James   is a renowned silent film accompanist and theater organist. Since 1971 he has accompanied films with symphony orchestras   and performed at major festivals       throughout North America and Europe, helping to revive the art of live music for silent pictures. He has been house organist for venues including El Capitan Theatre in Los Angeles and the Stanford Theatre in Palo Alto.   Since 2004, he has been a regular accompanist at the Orphan Film Symposium, beginning with his organ performance for the then-unidentified feature film given the title   The Fall of Jerusalem   . His Musica Curiosa performances feature his playing of unconventional instruments in a range of settings: glass armonica for a Mozart concert, theremin to accompany   Aelita: Queen of Mars   (1924), or seraphim on an album with Linda Ronstadt.   His academic appointments include being a Research Fellow in the Film and Media Studies Program at the University of South Carolina and Lecturer in the Music Department at Rutgers University.                   Vojtěch Jasný                                       Since the       beginning of his career as a filmmaker in 1950,   Vojtěch Jasný   has made sixty-one       films in countries all over the world, including in his       native Czech Republic / Czechoslovakia.       He has won numerous awards and honors for his work, among them the 1963 Special       Jury Prize and the       1969 Best Director award at the Cannes Film Festival, where       he was a member of the jury in 1970. He is currently at work on a film about       Terezín/Theresienstadt, and teaches at the New York Film Academy.               Mona Jimenez   teaches video and digital media preservation in NYU’s MIAP program and organizes for the preservation of independent media, asking questions like: why isn’t there a National Registry for Television and Video? or a funding stream for media, similar to the National Film Preservation Foundation? She started MIAP’s international initiative Audiovisual Preservation Exchange, and with collaborator Kara Van Malssen, leads teams of archivists to Accra, Ghana, to work with caretakers of audiovisual collections.               Martin L. Johnson   is a lecturer in the American Studies at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. He received his doctorate in cinema studies from New York University in January 2012. He has published articles in   The Moving Image   , and has forthcoming articles in   Historical Journal of Film, Radio, and Television   , and the edited volume   Beyond the Screen: Institutions, Networks and Publics of Early Cinema   . He attended Orphans 4 at the University of South Carolina in 2004 and was a contributing editor for the Orphan Film Symposium blog in 2008.               Larry Jones   is a Seattle attorney and sociologist. He has been an advocate for persons with intellectual and other developmental disabilities for 35 years, and has been searching for the lost film   Children Limited   almost as long. A past president of the advocacy organization known as the Arc of Washington, he was recognized as its National Volunteer of the Year in 1984. He is the author of   Doing Disability Justice: 75 Years of Family Advocacy   (Lulu Press, 2010).     www.seattledisabilitylaw.com.                 Catherine Jurca     is a Professor of English in the Division of the Humanities and Social Sciences at the California Institute of Technology. Her research interests revolve around twentieth-century American literature and film. She is the author of   White Diaspora: The Suburb and the Twentieth-Century American Novel   (2001). Her latest book   Hollywood 1938: Motion Pictures' Greatest Year   (2012) looks into public relations in the industry during a critical time when Hollywood needed to win back its audience.               Jonathan Kahana   teaches in the departments of Film and Digital Media at the University of California, Santa Cruz and Cinema Studies at Tisch School of the Arts, NYU. He is the author of   Intelligence Work: The Politics of American Documentary   (2008), and the editor of   The Documentary Film Reader: History, Theory, Criticism   , forthcoming from Oxford University Press.                 Sergei Kapterev   is Senior Researcher at Moscow’s Research Institute of Film Art and teaches history of world cinema at the Russian State Institute of Cinema (VGIK). He received his PhD in cinema studies from NYU and specializes in the intellectual and political aspects of interaction between Soviet and American cinemas. His other interests include Soviet propaganda film, cinema cultures of the late Stalin period and the post-Stalin “thaw,” Russian and Soviet films in and about the Far East, Cold War cinema, and theory and practice of film editing and sound.               Laura Kissel   is an Emmy-nominated documentary filmmaker whose work explores social/cultural landscapes, the representation of history, and the use of orphan films. She has been named a MacDowell Fellow (2006) and South Carolina Arts Commission Media Arts Fellow for 2007-08. Her documentary   Beyond the Classroom: China   (2007) garnered a CINE Golden Eagle Award and three Telly awards. Kissel was a 2009 Fulbright Fellow (Fudan University), shooting a documentary (   Cotton Road   ) while living in Shanghai.               Craig Kridel   is the Professor of Education Studies and Curator of the   Museum of Education at the University of South Carolina. His research interests include progressive education and school-related documentary film. He is currently completing work on the African American school documentary   , One Tenth of Our Nation   . He also recently published   Stories of the Eight Year Study   and edited   The Encyclopedia of Curriculum Studies   . Kridel is a Benton Scholar at the University of Chicago and was 2011 Scholar-in-Residence at the Rockefeller Archive Center, where he continued his research into educational film of the 1930s and 40s.               Yongli Li   is a film archivist for the University of South Carolina's Moving Image Research Collections. A native of Shanghai, she earned a bachelors degree from Communication University of China (formerly the Beijing Broadcasting Institute) and recently completed her MA in International Film Studies from Beijing Film Academy. For the past two years, she has helped to inventory and catalog the Chinese Film Collection and to program the Chinese Film Festival for the local art house theater, the Nickelodeon.               Jeanne Liotta   is a New York City-based artist, filmmaker, educator, and a 2012 Helen Hill Award recipient. Liotta’s works have been celebrated in festivals and museums around the world at the New York Film Festival, the Museum of Modern Art, and the Whitney Museum. She has received awards from the Jerome Foundation, New York State Council on the Arts, and the Museum of Contemporary Cinema among others. Liotta began making Super 8 films in 1988 and continues to work in 16mm, as well as digital video. Her first film,   Blue Moon,   is being preserved by Bill Brand of BB Optics and NYU students in the Moving Image Archiving and Preservation program. In addition to her work as a creator, Liotta is also active in the preservation community and has done significant research in the Joseph Cornell collection at Anthology Film Archives, and was the       creative       force behind the outdoor screening series Firefly Cinema. She is currently an assistant professor of film studies at the University of Colorado, Boulder, as well as member of the faculty at the Milton Avery Graduate School for the Arts at Bard College.               Alice Lovejoy   is       Assistant Professor in the Department of Cultural Studies and Comparative       Literature at the University of Minnesota, and a former       editor at       Film Comment   . Her recent publications       include essays in       Screen   ,       The Moving Image   , and the 2011 anthology       Opening Bazin: Postwar Film Theory and its       Afterlife   . Lovejoy is completing a book about Czechoslovakia’s       Army Film studio.               Irene Lusztig   is Assistant Professor in Film and Digital Media at UC Santa Cruz and an independent filmmaker. Her teaching interests include film and video production and editing, experimental documentary, and ethnographic film. She has received grants and fellowships from       the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study,       Massachusetts Foundation for the Humanities, Massachusetts Cultural Council, LEF Foundation, and New York State Council for the Arts. Lusztig’s recent projects include   The Worry Box Project   (2011),   The Motherhood Archives   (work in progress),   Class Notes   (in progress), and   The Samantha Smith Project   (2005). Lusztig received her BA in filmmaking and Chinese Studies from Harvard and completed her MFA in Film and Video at Bard College.               Jodie Mack   is Assistant Professor of Film and Media Studies at Dartmouth College. Recipient of the 2010 Orphan Film Symposium's Helen Hill Award, she works in various forms of cut-out and stop-motion animation. Her films use collage to investigate the relationship between graphic cinema and storytelling. Mack received an MFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago in 2007. She has taught animation at several colleges and spends her free time making pop-up cards and coordinating animation screenings.  She created the experimental film and video series Eyewash.               Robert Martens   is an art and special education school teacher living in Queens, New York, with his wife Marianne. When he’s not busy with schoolwork, he’s digitizing and putting online the historic film collection of his late grandfather Gustave Martens. It was in one of those rusting tin cans from grandpa's basement that Robert discovered the Auroratone film featured on this year’s program. An aspiring filmmaker himself, his current project is an animated featurette starring the 1960s comic book superhero, Herbie Popnecker. He programs a YouTube channel at YouTube.com/RobertWMartens.               Katy Martin   is a visual artist whose work combines painting, photography, and performance. Her art has been exhibited internationally at the Museum of Modern Art, NYC; Galerie Forum Am Meer, Berlin; Green Dog Arts, Northern Ireland; and the Shanghai Duolun Museum of Art. This spring, she has a solo exhibition at Saint Peter’s Church in New York. She has also curated numerous exhibitions of Chinese media art in the U.S. (Thomas Erben Gallery, Anthology Film Archives) and American film/video in China (MoCA Shanghai). Her writing on film and video has been published in   Millennium Film Journal   (New York) and Art World Magazine (Shanghai).               Louis Massiah   is an independent documentary filmmaker whose works include   W.E.B. Du Bois - A Biography in Four Voices,     The Bombing of Osage Avenue,   as well as episodes of the   Eyes on the Prize II   television series and a profile of acivil rights activist,   Cecil B. Moor.   He     recently completed a five-channel installation for the National Parks Service’s President’s House site in Philadelphia. Massiah is the founder and executive director of the Scribe Video Center in Philadelphia, a media arts organization that provides workshops and equipment access to emerging video/filmmakers and community organizations. A MacArthur Foundation “genius award” recipient, Massiah is the Lang Visiting Professor for Issues of Social Change at Swarthmore College.               Anna McCarthy   is an associate professor of cinema studies at NYU. She is the author of   Ambient Television   (2001) and   The Citizen Machine   (2010). She is also the co-editor of the journal   Social Text   . Her research interests are   television history, sponsored film, education film, history of technology, material culture, cultural policy, governmentality, trauma, and biopolitics.               Anke Mebold   works as film archivist, restorer, and DVD publicist at Deutsches Filminstitut – DIF in Frankfurt, Germany.   Die Hochbahnkatastrophe   (1921) from Valy Arnheim's Harry Hill detective series is her most recent major restoration project, preceded by Asta Nielsen's   Hamlet   (1920). Current responsibilities at DIF include work on a large collection of advertising films produced by the company Insel-Film in the 1950s and 60s, and a digitization project focused on films of WWI. She holds a certificate in film preservation from the L. Jeffrey Selznick School at George Eastman House, and a bachelor's degree in both Media Arts and Creative Writing from the University of Arizona. Her publications include articles on restoration projects, Lotte Reiniger's silhouette animation films, and on the history and spread of the 28mm film gauge.               Barbara Miller   is Collection Curator at Museum of the Moving Image. She received a PhD in anthropology from New York University.               Charles Musser   is a documentary filmmaker and Professor of American Studies, Film Studies, and Theater Studies at Yale University. He is the author of several books on early cinema, including   High-Class Moving Pictures: Lyman H. Howe and the Forgotten Era of Traveling Exhibition, 1880-1920   (1990).     His study of Carl Marzani and Union Films, first presented at the sixth Orphan Film     Symposium, appeared in the Spring 2009 issue of The Moving Image. He has just finished making a new documentary titled   Errol Morris: A Lightning Sketch   .               Julia Noordegraaf   is Associate Professor in the Department of Media Studies at the University of Amsterdam and Director of the international master’s program Preservation and Presentation of the Moving Image. Her research focuses on the preservation and exhibition of audiovisual heritage and has been published in journals such as   The Moving Image   ,   Cinema & Cie,   and   Critical Studies in Television   . In 2010 Noordegraaf was a fellow at the Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study in the Humanities and Social Sciences. She chairs the Publications Committee of the Association of Moving Image Archivists and is a member of the   International Network for Trans-disciplinary Research   , and the   Network for the Conservation of Contemporary Art Research   . She also is editor of the Dutch   Tijdschrift voor Mediageschiedenis   (Journal of Media History).               Sunniva O’Flynn   is Curator of the Irish Film Institute, programming both new Irish productions and material from the IFI Irish Film Archive. Recent curatorial projects include   This Other Eden: Ireland and Film   at the National Gallery of Art in Washington; the co-curation with Gabriel Byrne of   Revisiting   The Quiet Man   : Ireland on Film   at the Museum of Modern Art, New York; and a series of programs bringing archival films back to the Irish communities from whence they came. Highlights in 2011 included   Journey to Aran   (a program of silent films of the Aran Islands with a devised score by local musicians) and   The Seasons   (a film from 1935 presented with Irish traditional harp).               Devin Orgeron   is Associate Professor and Chair of Film Studies at North Carolina State University. He is the author of   Road Movies   (2007). His articles have appeared in   Cinema Journal   ,   The Velvet Light Trap   ,   Film Quarterly   , and   The Moving Image   . He coedited   Learning With the Lights Off: Educational Film in the United States   (2012) with Dan Streible and Marsha Orgeron. He is also writing a book about contemporary American directors and their work in advertising.               Marsha Orgeron   is Associate Professor and of Film Studies at North Carolina State University.   She is the author of   Hollywood Ambitions: Celebrity in the Movie Age   (2008).   She is also the co-editor of   Learning with the Lights Off: Educational Film in the United States   (2012) and an editor-in-chief for   The Moving Image   , journal of the Association for Moving Image Archivists.               Stephen Parr   -- archivist, imagemaker, and curator -- is director of both Oddball Film + Video and the San Francisco Media Archive. He has a long history of presenting and archiving the unusual. Since the 1970s Parr has produced and documented live performances by (among others) John Cage and the Ramones. His signature pop culture compilations have screened in nightclubs and universities around the world. His found footage-based programs, such as "Historical/Hysterical" and "Eurphoria,” have screened at venues including Anthology Film Archives, Jaaga (Bangalore), and the Leeds International Film Festival. He curates an eclectic weekly film series in San Francisco.               Jaime Partsch   is the historian in charge of the Jesús T. Piñero Collection at the   Universidad del Este   in Carolina, Puerto Rico, looking over the film preservation project of the collection for over seven years. He is the author of   Jesús T. Piñero: El exiliado en su patria   (2006) and   La crisis de 1898 y su impacto sobre los institutos de vida religiosa en Puerto Rico   (2007). Partsch received his BA in Sociology at the University of Puerto Rico and his PhD in History at the Center for Advanced Studies of Puerto Rico and the Caribbean, San Juan, Puerto Rico.       Lydia Pappas   is assistant director at the University of South Carolina's Moving Image Research Collections, where she is also curator of regional films and of the Chinese Film Collection. Previously was film archivist for the City of London (London Metropolitan Archives) and librarian at the Royal Society of Medicine. She earned an MA degree in Film Archiving from the University of East Anglia.       Eugene Perl   attended Hessian Hills School in Croton-on-Hudson, New York. In 1939 he appeared in the film   School: A Film about Progressive Education.               Elizabeth Peterson   is Librarian for Literature & Cinema Studies at the University of Oregon.               Rick Prelinger   is an archivist, teacher, writer, lecturer, and filmmaker. He is the president of                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Prelinger Archives, which held over 60,000 ephemeral films and over 40,000 cans of unedited footage, and the co-founder of the Prelinger Library in San Francisco. In 2002, the Library of Congress acquired the archives’ core film collection. Prelinger is the editor/producer/director of the feature-length archival film   Panorama Ephemera   (2004), among many others.               Dana Polan f   is a professor of Cinema Studies at NYU. He is the author of, most recently   , Julia Child's The French Chef       and has begun work on a new manuscript tentatively titled   The Square Screen: Reflections on the Unhip Cinema of the 1960s   .               Mark Quigley   is an access archivist for UCLA Film & Television Archive. His interests include orphan television productions, broadcast ephemera, and public service films.               Leenke Ripmeester   finished her doctoral dissertation, "Permitted Performativities: The Construction of Youth in Music Videos," in 2006 at the University of Amsterdam. Since 2007 she has been working at the film collection department of EYE Film Institute Netherlands, disclosing the Geesink collection and other collections of animation and commissioned films. In 2009 she organized a workshop on advertising films for EYE. She is also a projectionist.               Elena Rossi-Snook   is the moving image archivist for the Reserve Film and Video Collection of The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. She has an MA in Film Archiving from the University of East Anglia and was the 2002 recipient of the Kodak Fellowship in Film Preservation.  She teaches film history at Pratt Institute and is a contributing author to the recently published   Learning with the Lights Off   (2012).               Ivan von Sauer   is the Director of Development for Education at BBC Worldwide in New York. He has previously worked in archival footage at Getty Images and Archive Films.       Also an artist, his video installations have been shown at the Museum of Modern Art and Whitney Museum of American Art in New York.               Lillian Schwartz   is most widely recognized for her innovative use of computer graphics in her artwork and filmmaking. While artist in residence at Bell Labs, she collaborated with top engineers, computer scientists, and pioneering electronic music composers to make films such as   Pixillation   (1971),   Googolplex   (1972),     and   Papillons   (1973). The "mother of digital art" has taught at NYU, Rutgers, and the University of Maryland in both Computer Science and Arts Departments. (See her website: lillian.com)               David Schwartz   is the chief curator at Museum of the Moving Image. He received his BFA in Film from SUNY Purchase in 1984 and began working for the museum shortly after. He is responsible for curating and supervising all of the museums film and video programs, including the online exhibition The Living Room Candidate (see livingroomcandidate.org). He is also editor for the museum's online publication,   Moving Image Source   (movingimage.us). Schwartz is also a visiting professor of cinema studies at SUNY Purchase.               Jay Schwartz   is the founder of Philadelphia’s floating repertory cinema series, the Secret Cinema. For twenty years, he has been bringing unique programming to   nightclubs, bars, coffee houses, museums, open fields, colleges, art galleries, bookstores, theaters and film festivals. Drawing on his large private archive as well as other collections, he explores uncharted territory and the genres that fall between the cracks. Secret Cinema is devoted to educational and industrial films, cult and exploitation features, jukebox films, rare television, local history, politically incorrect material, and other orphaned categories of celluloid.               Susan Selig   has worked in the entertainment industry since 1983 and for Kodak since 1994. Since 2009 she has been the Marketing Communication Specialist for Kodak's Entertainment Imaging Division.               Andrew Earle Simpson   is a composer, pianist, organist. and professor at the Benjamin T. Rome School of Music of The Catholic University of America in Washington, DC. As a silent film musician, Simpson is Resident Film Accompanist at the National Gallery of Art, and House Accompanist at the Library of Congress Mt. Pony Theater in Culpeper, Virginia. He has also performed original scores for silent films across the U.S. and abroad. He has recorded works for labels such as Naxos, Albany, Fleur de Son Classics, Capstone, and others.               Amy Sloper   has been the assistant film conservator at the Harvard Film Archive since 2007, where she conserves, catalogs, and makes accessible a film collection of over 24,000 titles. Prior to that she studied at UCLA's Moving Image Archive Studies program and held positions at the iota Center and the Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles. Her favorite genres of orphan films are home movies, feminist menstruation films, and dental surgery films.               Composer/pianist   Donald Sosin   played at Orphans 7, and is well-known to silent film audiences and scholars around the world for the scope and variety of his work over the past four decades. A graduate of the University of Michigan and Columbia University, he performs, often with his wife Joanna Seaton, at MoMA, MOMI, Lincoln Center, the National Gallery of Art, and other museums. Sosin worked on Broadway for many years, and writes and arranges for TV, radio and video. His current projects include DVD scores for Milestone and the Criterion Collection.                Jacqueline Stewart   is Associate Professor of Radio, Television, Film and African American Studies at Northwestern University.   Her research and teaching interests focus on African American film, literature and culture, American silent film, cinemas of the African Diaspora, and Chicago media history. In 2005, she published   Migrating to the Movies: Cinema and Black Urban Modernity   ,   and her essays have appeared in journals including   Critical Inquiry   ,   Film Quarterly   ,   Film History   and   The Moving Image   .   She directs the South Side Home Movie Project, and is co-curator of the L.A. Rebellion Preservation Project at the UCLA Film and Television Archive. She is currently researching the history of Black moving image preservation, and completing a study of the life and work of African American actor/writer/director Spencer Williams.               Rachael Stoeltje     is the film archivist overseeing Indiana University Libraries’ extensive film holdings.       Over the past 14 years, she has established and implemented preservation and access policies for four Indiana University film collections: the Kinsey Institute, the Lilly Library’s David Bradley and Peter Bogdanovich film collections, and the older educational film collection now held by the Libraries She also a member of the Media Preservation Initiative on the IU campus.               Dan Streible   is director of the Orphan Film Project and symposium. With Devin and Marsha Orgeron he co-edited the book   Learning with the Lights Off: Educational Film in the United Sates   (Oxford University Press, 2012). For his book proposal   Orphan Films: Saving, Screening, and Studying Neglected Cinema,   the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences awarded him a 2012 Academy Film Scholar grant.               Mark Street   is an independent filmmaker, curator, and educator. He is Associate Professor of Film in the Visual Art Department at Fordham University-Lincoln Center, where he teaches film/video production and other courses that engage     contemporary artistic practice. His work has shown internationally in museums and film festivals as the New York Museum of Modern Art, Anthology Film Archives, Sundance, Rotterdam, London, San Francisco, and South by Southwest. His essay on film funding, "Who’s Asking?   "   appeared in   Millennium Film Journal   .               Nancy McLean Suniewick   is partner and comptroller of Colorlab Corp., which Russ Suniewick founded in 1972. Older daughter of Hector Frederick McLean, known as “Mac.”  Mac and Bill Birch were both born in 1918. When they met as pre-teens in Chicago, they became close friends. Each was an only child and became the brother neither had. Bill and Mac’s widow [Nancy’s mother] kept in contact for a few years after Mac’s death in 1957 at age 38. In a wonderful twist of fate, Nancy reconnected with Bill Birch at the fifth Orphan Film Symposium in 2006.                   Russ Suniewick   is the president of Colorlab, one of the major film preservation laboratories servicing film-to-film as well as film-to-digital preservation for small gauge-formats to 35mm. Has worked on many preservation projects for clients such as the Library of Congress, U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, Smithsonian's Human Studies Film Archive, Tokyo Peace Museum, and National Library of Ireland.   Suniewick is an Orphans regular and has provided preservation services for the symposium to make many of the screenings of rare moving image materials possible.               Dwight Swanson   is one of the founding board members of the Center for Home Movies and the producer of the home movie compilation film   Amateur Night: Home Movies from American Archives.   Since graduating from the L. Jeffrey Selznick School of Film Preservation at the George Eastman House he has served as the archivist for regional film and video collections in the U.S. He has also lectured and written extensively on home movies and amateur film, including presentations at the Orphan Film Symposium, the Northeast Historic Film Summer Symposium, the University Film and Video Association, and the Association of Moving Image Archivists’ annual conferences.               Mark J. Williams   is an associate professor of film and media at Dartmouth College. He has published in journals and anthologies, including   Télévision: le moment expérimental (1935-1955)   ;   New Media: Theories and Practices of Digitextuality   ;   Collecting Visible Evidence   ;   Dietrich Icon   ;   Television, History, and American Culture: Feminist Critical Essays   ; and   Living Color: Race, Feminism, and Television   . He directed the Leslie Center Humanities Institute entitled Cyber-Disciplinarity. In conjunction with the Dartmouth College Library, he is the founding editor of an e-journal, the   Journal of e-Media Studies   . With Adrian Randolph, he co-edits the book series Interfaces: Studies in Visual Culture for the University Press of New England. His book   Remote Possibilities   : A   History of Early Television in Los Angeles   will be published by Duke University Press.               Greg Wilsbacher   is Curator of Newsfilm Collections, including the Fox Movietone News Collection, at the University of South Carolina’s Moving Image Research Collections.   His past research includes “Fox News Librarianship, 1919 to 1925: An Evolving Practice,” which sought to acquire a better understanding of how Fox News organized and cataloged the newsreel film and associated paperwork that camera crews submitted.               Audrey Young   is the Project Director of Archivo Memoria, an innovative program at the Cineteca Nacional México that seeks to preserve neglected moving images through reutilization in new creative projects. She is a graduate of the NYU MIAP program.               Yvonne Zimmermann   is an assistant professor in the   Department of Cinema Studies   at the University of Zurich and currently a visiting research scholar at NYU   (2011-2013). She has published widely on the subjects of documentary, nontheatrical exhibition, sponsored and industrial film. Zimmermann's new book,   Schaufenster Schweiz: Dokumentarische Gebrauchsfilme 1896-1964,   examines the historical uses of nonfiction films in Switzerland. Her current research project addresses Hans Richter's sponsored films (1937-1941) and the transatlantic transfer of his documentary concepts.                                     Orphan Film Project     |     Orphan 8 Home     |     Museum of the Moving                                                          No labels                                                                                                                                       Need help?
